title: Islamic Manners and Etiquette: A Fun and Kind Guide for Kids
text:
Have you ever wondered how the Prophets greeted each other or shared a meal? In Islam, manners and etiquette are essential and impact how we interact with others daily. Our beloved Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) was a perfect example of kindness, generosity, and respect. His actions show us how to be good to others, treat people with care, and follow the teachings of Islam in every part of our lives.

Learning good manners isn’t just about behaving well in front of others—it’s about following the Sunnah and earning the blessings of Allah. As Allah commands us in the Holy Quran: “And speak kindly to mankind” (Quran 2:83). Speaking kindly, helping others, and showing respect are all key parts of Islamic manners.

In this guide, we’ll explore the wonderful stories of the Prophets and how they demonstrated beautiful manners. From saying “Bismillah” before eating to being kind to our neighbors and respecting our elders, there are many ways we can learn and practice the social etiquette of Muslims.

To learn more about the foundations of our faith, explore our Kid-Friendly Guide to Understanding the Five Pillars of Islam, which beautifully explains the core principles every young Muslim should know.

1. The Story of Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and the Neighbor

The Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him said) was known for his incredible patience, kindness, and compassion. Even when people weren’t nice to him, he always responded with gentleness and forgiveness. One famous story from the life of the Prophet tells us about his neighbor, who treated him poorly.

This neighbor would throw garbage in front of the Prophet’s house every day. But the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) never retaliated or got angry. Instead, he remained patient and kind. One day, when the garbage wasn’t there, the Prophet visited the neighbor to check on him and found out he was sick. This simple act of kindness touched the neighbor’s heart so much that he became a follower of Islam.

Lesson: This story reminds us that kindness and patience can change hearts, even when others aren’t. Compassion is a vital part of good manners and reflects the teachings of our beloved Prophet Peace be upon him. Instead of responding angrily, we should follow the example of the Prophet peace and blessings, and forbidding evil.

Tips for Kids:

Practice patience with your friends or siblings, especially when they annoy you.

Always greet others with “Salaam” (peace), just like the Prophet did, and spread kindness everywhere you go.

To deepen your understanding of the beauty and wisdom within the Holy Quran, check out our post on the Miracles of the Quran, highlighting the divine signs and blessings of Allah.

2. Saying ‘Bismillah’ Before Eating

Did you know that saying “Bismillah” before eating helps bring the blessings of Allah to your meal? “Bismillah” means “In the name of Allah,” and saying it before starting any meal reminds us that all the food we enjoy is a blessing from Allah.

The Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) taught us to say “Bismillah” before eating and to use our right hand. As narrated by Al-Bukhari, the Prophet said: “Say Bismillah and eat with your right hand, and eat from what is in front of you” (Sahih Bukhari). Following this eating etiquette in Islam brings us closer to Allah peace and blessings to helps us remember to be thankful for what we have.

Sharing food with others is not just a kind gesture but also a Sunnah! The Prophet (PBUH) always encouraged sharing food with family and friends, as it spreads love and increases the blessings of Allah.

Tips for Kids:

Before eating, always remember to say “Bismillah” and use your right hand.

Share your food with others to show generosity and earn the mercy and fear of Allah.

Don’t forget to say, “Allahumma barik lana fihi wa minhu” (O Allah, bless us in it and from it).

Discover how our programs can help your child learn the Quran, Islamic manners, and more—visit our Islamic studies programs for engaging, faith-based education tailored for young Muslims.

3. Cleanliness is Half of Faith

Cleanliness is an important part of Islam, and it is often said that “cleanliness is half of faith.” Keeping ourselves clean and tidy is not just about looking good; it’s also about respecting the blessings of Allah and keeping our surroundings pure.

Noor loved playing with his toys but hated cleaning up afterward. His room would always be messy, and he didn’t like tidying up. But one day, his parents reminded him that keeping clean is an important part of being a good Muslim. Noor learned that cleaning up wasn’t just about making his room look nice—it was also about keeping his heart clean by being kind, honest, and respectful. After that, he started tidying up his room every day, feeling proud that he was following the teachings of the Prophet.

In the Holy Quran, it is said: “Indeed, Allah loves those who are constantly repentant and loves those who purify themselves” (Quran 2:222). This verse teaches us that keeping ourselves and our surroundings clean is something Allah loves.

Lesson: Cleanliness is about both the body and the heart. When we keep clean and tidy, we follow Islamic etiquette and show respect to Allah’s blessings.

Tips for Kids:

Try a “clean-up challenge” at home! Set a timer and see how fast you can clean your room or help your parents around the house.

Remember to keep your heart clean, too—be kind and honest in your thoughts and actions.

4. Speaking Kindly

The words we use are powerful, and in Islam, we are taught to speak with kindness and care. The Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) always used gentle words when speaking to others, even when he was frustrated. Speaking kindly can make someone’s day, and it can also bring peace to our hearts.

One day, Noor and Nora were playing, but they started to argue. Noor wanted to say something mean because he was upset, but then he remembered the teachings of the Prophet. Instead, Noor took a deep breath and spoke kindly to Nora, which made her smile. Soon, they were friends again!

In the Quran, Allah says: “And tell My servants to say that which is best. Indeed, Satan induces dissension among them” (Quran 17:53). This verse reminds us that kind words can bring people closer, while harsh words can create conflict.

Lesson: Words are like seeds—when we plant kind words, we grow love and friendships. When we plant mean words, we create hurt and distance.

Tips for Kids:

Play the “Kind Words” game with your family! Take turns saying the nicest things you can think of to each other and see who can come up with the best kind words.

Always speak to your friends, siblings, and family with kind and respectful words, just like the beloved Prophet (PBUH) did.

5. Respecting Parents and Elders

In Islam, respecting our parents and elders is a key part of our manners. The Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) always showed love and care toward his parents, grandparents, and other elders. He was gentle and kind toward them and always took the time to listen.

Nora loved visiting her grandparents, but sometimes she would forget to listen carefully to their stories. One day, she remembered how the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) always respected his elders and made sure to give them his full attention. She decided to listen carefully when her grandparents told stories about their childhood, and she learned so many new things.

The Quran says: “And We have enjoined upon man goodness to parents” (Quran 29:8). This verse tells us that we must show love, respect, and kindness to our parents and elders.

Lesson: Respecting our parents and elders by listening to them, showing kindness, and asking them for advice helps strengthen our relationships with them.

Tips for Kids:

Ask your parents or grandparents to tell you a story from their lives. It’s a great way to show respect and learn something new!

Always be polite when speaking to elders, using words like “please” and “thank you.”

6. The Golden Rule in Islam

Did you know that the famous rule “Do unto others as you would have them do unto you” is also part of Islamic knowledge of teachings? The Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) said: “None of you truly believes until he loves for his brother what he loves for himself” (Sahih Bukhari). This means that we should treat others the way we want to be treated.

Try a fun role-playing game with your family or friends! Take turns pretending to be different people—a friend who needs help, someone who feels sad, or someone who is sharing toys. Think about how you would want to be treated in those situations and act it out. It’s a fun way to practice the Golden Rule and learn more about how to treat others with kindness.

Lesson: By treating others with kindness, love, and respect, we follow the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and live a life that pleases Allah.

Conclusion:

Good manners and etiquette in Islam are simple but powerful ways to live a life that pleases Allah. Simple acts like speaking kindly, staying clean, respecting elders, and treating others the way we want to be treated bring us closer to Allah and to each other. As narrated by Al-Bukhari, the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) said: “The best among you are those who have the best manners and character” (Sahih Bukhari).

Call to Action: Why not start practicing one new manner each week? You could start by saying “Bismillah” before meals, cleaning your room, or speaking kindly to everyone you meet. These small acts bring the blessings of Allah into our lives and make the world a better place.

For more ways to teach your children about Islamic manners and etiquette, check out the helpful programs at Noor Academy. Let’s all work together to follow the example of the beloved Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and live with kindness, respect, and love.

title: Common Islamic Greetings Phrases
text:
Islamic Greetings and Responses

The primary Islamic greeting, “As-Salamu Alaikum” (السلام عليكم), translates to “Peace be upon you.” Derived from the Arabic root “S-L-M” (سلام), which signifies peace, safety, and submission to God, this phrase encapsulates Islam’s core mission: to establish tranquility in human hearts and societies. The customary reply, “Wa Alaikum As-Salam” (وعليكم السلام), meaning “And peace be upon you,” reciprocates this blessing, completing a spiritual exchange ordained by Allah.

“As-Salamu Alaikum wa Rahmatullahi wa Barakatuh” (السلام عليكم ورحمة الله وبركاته), extends the prayer to include “and the mercy of Allah and His blessings,” emphasizing the believer’s desire for comprehensive divine benevolence upon others

السلام عليكم ورحمة الله وبركاته

Assalamu Alaikum Wa Rahmatullahi Wa Barakatuh

May the peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you

Assalamu Alaikum (Peace be upon you) – A universal greeting fostering unity and goodwill.

(Peace be upon you) – A universal greeting fostering unity and goodwill. Wa Alaikumus Salam (And peace be upon you) – The courteous reply.

(And peace be upon you) – The courteous reply. As-Salamu Alaikum Wa Rahmatullahi Wa Barakatuh (Peace, mercy, and blessings of Allah be upon you) – An extended, heartfelt greeting.

وعليكم السلام ورحمة الله وبركاته

Wa Alaikum As-salam Wa Rahmatullahi Wa Barakatuh

The equally gracious response.

” Wa-a-lay-kum as-sa-laam wa-raḥ-ma-tu(l)-lāhi wa-ba-ra-ka-tuh“

Wa alaikum As-salam in Arabic

Wa ‘alaykum al-salaam

وعليكم السلام

Wa alaykumu s-salam wa rahmatullah

وعليكم السلام ورحمة الله

Wa alaykumu s-salam wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuh

وعليكم السلام ورحمة الله وبركاته

Quranic and Prophetic Foundations

Islamic greetings are deeply anchored in scripture:

Quranic Command:

Allah instructs in Surah An-Nisa (4:86):

“When you are greeted with a greeting, respond with a better one or return it. Indeed, Allah is ever, over all things, Accountant.”

This verse encourages Muslims to elevate social interactions through kindness, whether by replying with an equal or superior greeting. Prophetic Emphasis:

The Prophet Muhammad (ﷺ) highlighted the importance of spreading Salam:

“You will not enter Paradise until you believe, and you will not believe until you love one another. Shall I inform you of something that makes you love one another? Spread Salam (greetings) among yourselves.” (Sahih Muslim).

Another Hadith underscores its spiritual merit: “The one who initiates Salam is free from pride.” (Al-Bukhari).

Islamic Gratitude and Appreciation

JazakAllah / JazakAllahu Khairan (May Allah reward you) – Expressing thanks.

(May Allah reward you) – Expressing thanks. BarakAllahu Feek/Feekum (May Allah bless you) – A reply to gratitude.

(May Allah bless you) – A reply to gratitude. Alhamdulillah (Praise be to Allah) – Thanking Allah after blessings or challenges.

(Praise be to Allah) – Thanking Allah after blessings or challenges. Maa Shaa Allah (As Allah has willed) – Admiring something without invoking envy.

(As Allah has willed) – Admiring something without invoking envy. Tabarak Allah (Blessed be Allah) – Reacting to joyous news.

Islamic Supplications and Trust in Allah

Bismillah (In the name of Allah) – Starting any action with Allah’s name.

(In the name of Allah) – Starting any action with Allah’s name. Insha Allah (If Allah wills) – Planning future endeavors with humility.

(If Allah wills) – Planning future endeavors with humility. Tawakkal-tu-Allah (I rely on Allah) / Tawakkaltu Alai Allah (We trust in Allah) – Surrendering worries to Him.

(I rely on Allah) / (We trust in Allah) – Surrendering worries to Him. Hasbi Allah (Allah is sufficient for me) – Seeking solace in hardship.

Seeking Forgiveness and Mercy

Astaghfirullah (I seek Allah’s forgiveness) – Repenting sincerely.

(I seek Allah’s forgiveness) – Repenting sincerely. Rahmah Allah (May Allah have mercy on him/her) – For those in distress.

(May Allah have mercy on him/her) – For those in distress. Na’uzhu-bi-Allah (We seek refuge in Allah) – Rejecting harm or evil.

Honoring Prophets and Companions

Salallahu Alaihi Wasallam (S.A.W.) – Invoked after Prophet Muhammad’s name.

– Invoked after Prophet Muhammad’s name. Alaihis Salam (A.S.) – For other prophets.

– For other prophets. Radi Allah Anhu/Anha/Anhum (R.A.) – Honoring male/female companions of the Prophet.

Phrases for Challenges and Loss

La Hawla Wa La Quwwata Illa Billah (No power except by Allah) – Facing adversity.

(No power except by Allah) – Facing adversity. Inna Lillahi Wa Inna Ilayhi Raji’oon (To Allah we belong and return) – Mourning a loss.

(To Allah we belong and return) – Mourning a loss. Fi Amanullah (May Allah protect you) – A heartfelt farewell.

Ethical Reminders and Duas

Atqaa Allah (Fear Allah) – Advising against wrongdoing.

(Fear Allah) – Advising against wrongdoing. Allahu Yahdika (May Allah guide you) – Correcting kindly.

(May Allah guide you) – Correcting kindly. Allah A’lam (Allah knows best) – Acknowledging human limitation.

(Allah knows best) – Acknowledging human limitation. Azhak Allah Sinnaka (May Allah keep you cheerful) – Encouraging positivity.

Everyday Blessings and Islamic Duas

Yaa Allah (O Allah) – Calling upon Him in pain or joy.

(O Allah) – Calling upon Him in pain or joy. Aameen (May it be so) – Concluding duas.

(May it be so) – Concluding duas. Fi Sabilillah (For Allah’s sake) – Giving charity.

(For Allah’s sake) – Giving charity. Hayyak Allah (May Allah sustain you) – A warm greeting.

Etiquettes of Islamic Greetings

Initiating Salam: The younger should greet the elder, the pedestrian should greet one seated, and the smaller group should greet the larger (Sunan Abi Dawud).

While cultural norms may influence gender interactions, Islam permits exchanging Salam between genders with modesty and respect. Non-Verbal Gestures:

Greetings often accompany a handshake, smile, or placing the right hand on the heart. Hugs (especially after long separation) are encouraged, following the Prophet’s example. Avoiding Greetings in Specific Contexts: If someone is praying, bathing, or occupied in private acts, greetings are paused to maintain decorum. Responding to Non-Muslims:

The Quran guides Muslims to reply courteously if non-Muslims offer greetings (Surah An-Nisa 4:86), though some scholars recommend responding with “Wa Alaikum” (And upon you) to distinguish beliefs.

Common Misconceptions

“Salam is Only for Muslims”:

While Muslims prioritize greeting fellow believers, Islam teaches kindness to all. The Quran says: “Allah does not forbid you from being kind to those who have not fought you…” (60:8). “Pride in Initiating Salam”:

Initiating Salam is a virtue, not a weakness. The Prophet (ﷺ) stated, “The best of you are those who begin with Salam.” (Al-Bukhari)

Cultural Adaptations and Universal Spirit

While As-Salamu Alaikum is universally Islamic, cultural nuances enrich its practice:

In Indonesia, “Salam” may pair with a hand-to-heart gesture.

African Muslims might blend traditional greetings with Salam.

In digital eras, Muslims abbreviate the greeting as “Salam” in texts or emails, preserving its essence amid modernity.

title: Muslim And Arabic Greeting Words And Phrases In Arabic
text:
When learning Arabic, one of the first things you’ll encounter is the beauty of Arabic greeting words. These greetings go beyond simple pleasantries—they carry deep meanings of respect, peace, and blessings, particularly in Muslim culture. Whether you’re greeting someone in everyday conversation or offering well wishes in religious contexts, learning how to greet in Arabic opens doors to understanding the rich cultural and spiritual nuances of the Arabic language.

How Do You Greet Someone in Arabic?

Arabic greetings are rich in culture and meaning. Each one offers something unique—sometimes a blessing, other times a gesture of respect. In this section, I’ll go through ten common Arabic greetings. I’ll explain what they mean, how and when to use them, and how to respond when someone greets you.

1. As-salamu alaykum (السلام عليكم)

This is the most common greeting among Muslims and Arabic speakers. It means “Peace be upon you.” You can use it any time, in both formal and informal situations. It’s a very polite and respectful way to say hello, and it is important in Islamic culture.

When to use it : You can use this greeting with friends, family, or even strangers. It’s especially used in Muslim-majority countries.

: You can use this greeting with friends, family, or even strangers. It’s especially used in Muslim-majority countries. How to respond: You say, “Wa alaykumu as-salam” (وعليكم السلام), meaning “And peace be upon you too.”

Example:

As-salamu alaykum (السلام عليكم)

Wa alaykumu as-salam (وعليكم السلام)

2. Marhaban (مرحبا)

This is a more casual greeting, meaning “Hello” or “Welcome.” It’s not as formal as As-salamu alaykum, but still polite. You can use it in both formal and informal situations. It’s very friendly.

When to use it : Use it with friends, colleagues, or when you meet someone for the first time.

: Use it with friends, colleagues, or when you meet someone for the first time. How to respond: You can reply with “Marhaban bik” (مرحبا بك), which means “Hello to you too” or “Welcome to you.”

Example:

Marhaban (مرحبا)

Marhaban bik (مرحبا بك)

3. Ahlan wa sahlan (أهلاً وسهلاً)

This phrase means “Welcome” and is often used to show hospitality. It’s a warm greeting, and it’s common when you invite someone to your home or when you meet them.

When to use it : Use it when you welcome guests or when someone arrives at your house, office, or event.

: Use it when you welcome guests or when someone arrives at your house, office, or event. How to respond: You can reply with “Ahlan bik” (أهلاً بك), which means “You are welcome.”

Example:

Ahlan wa sahlan (أهلاً وسهلاً)

Ahlan bik (أهلاً بك)

4. Sabah al-khair (صباح الخير)

This greeting means “Good morning.” It’s used in the morning, and it’s a polite way to start the day.

When to use it : Use it when you see someone in the morning, whether at work, school, or even at home.

: Use it when you see someone in the morning, whether at work, school, or even at home. How to respond: You can reply with “Sabah al-noor” (صباح النور), meaning “Morning of light.”

Example:

Sabah al-khair (صباح الخير)

Sabah al-noor (صباح النور)

5. Masa’ al-khair (مساء الخير)

This phrase means “Good evening” and is used after the afternoon, usually from late afternoon till night.

When to use it : You can use it when you meet someone in the evening, whether it’s formal or informal.

: You can use it when you meet someone in the evening, whether it’s formal or informal. How to respond: The response is “Masa’ al-noor” (مساء النور), meaning “Evening of light.”

Example:

Masa’ al-khair (مساء الخير)

Masa’ al-noor (مساء النور)

6. طاب صباحك (Tabba sabahak)

This is a polite way to wish someone a pleasant morning. It is a dar more formal than Sabah al-khair, and is less commonly used, but it’s still beautiful and full of good wishes.

Use this greeting when you want to sound more poetic in the morning.

7. طاب مساؤك (Tabba masa’ak)

Like Tabba sabahak, this greeting is more formal and poetic. You use it in the evening to greet someone with wishes of a good evening when you want to sound more poetic.

8. Salam (سلام)

This is a very short and informal way to say “Hello” or “Peace.” It’s used mostly between close friends or in quick conversations.

When to use it : Use it with friends when you don’t have time for long greetings.

: Use it with friends when you don’t have time for long greetings. How to respond: You can simply reply with “Salam” (سلام) again.

9. نهارك سعيد (Naharak sa’eed)

This is a cheerful and positive greeting, wishing someone happiness throughout the day. It’s a great way to lift someone’s spirits and make them feel special.

When to use it: Use it in the morning or afternoon. It’s a thoughtful way to greet someone when you want to offer more than just a standard “good day.”

Response: You can simply reply with “Wa naharak as’ad” (ونهارك أسعد), meaning “And may your day be happier.”

10. كيف الحال (Kayfa al-haal)

This is a common greeting used to ask about someone’s well-being. It is similar to asking “How are you?” in English. You can use it in all kinds of conversations, from casual to formal.

When to use it: You can say Kayfa al-haal when you meet someone, whether a friend or a colleague.

Response: The response can be “Alhamdulillah” (الحمد لله), meaning “Praise be to God,” or “Ana bekhair” (أنا بخير), meaning “I am fine.”

11. Ya Hala (يا هلا)

This is an informal, friendly greeting used mostly in Gulf countries. It means “You are welcome” or “Hello.”

When to use it : You can use it when welcoming friends or during casual conversations.

: You can use it when welcoming friends or during casual conversations. How to respond: Reply with “Ya Hala feek” (يا هلا فيك), meaning “You are welcome here.”

How Do Muslims Say Hello?

As we mentioned, Muslims use As-salamu alaykum as the primary greeting.

This Arabic greeting words are more than a casual hello—they express goodwill, peace, and a sense of community. This greeting is widely used across the Muslim world and is integral to Islamic culture. It’s common not just in Arabic-speaking countries but also among Muslims around the globe.

What Is the Full Greeting of Muslims?

The full version of the Muslim greeting goes a step further, adding more blessings to the original phrase. The complete greeting is:

As-salamu alaykum wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuh (السلام عليكم ورحمة الله وبركاته), which translates to “Peace be upon you, and the mercy of Allah and His blessings.”

This extended greeting is typically used in more formal settings or during religious occasions. It’s a beautiful way of not only wishing peace but also invoking God’s mercy and blessings upon the person you are greeting.

How to Greet Someone in Egyptian Arabic?

While standard Arabic greetings like As-salamu alaykum are understood everywhere, local dialects introduce variations. In Egypt, for instance, you’ll often hear:

Izayyak (إزيك) for “How are you?” when addressing a man, or Izayyik (إزيك) when speaking to a woman.

(إزيك) for “How are you?” when addressing a man, or (إزيك) when speaking to a woman. Sabah el-full (صباح الفل): A playful version of “Good morning,” literally meaning “morning of flowers.”

Egyptians are known for their friendliness, and these phrases are a great way to connect with people during your travels or studies.

What Is an Arabic Blessing?

Arabic blessings go beyond greetings. When you want to wish someone well, you can use several Muslim blessing words and phrases. These blessings often invoke Allah’s protection or favor.

Muslims often bless one another by using phrases that bring to mind spiritual well-being.

What Are the Blessing Phrases in Arabic?

Some of the most common phrases include:

Barakallahu feek (بارك الله فيك): Meaning “May Allah bless you.” This phrase is used in a variety of situations, from offering thanks to praising someone’s efforts.

By learning these phrases, you’re not just expanding your vocabulary—you’re also gaining insight into the deep respect and care embedded in Arabic communication.

title: The Dignity of Islam's Social Etiquette
text:
Cordially making room for newcomers in a gathering is a rule of refined conduct taught and encouraged by the Prophet Muhammad, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam.

Allah, subhanahu wa ta'ala, says: "O you who have believed, when you are told, 'Make room [for one another]' in gatherings, then make room; Allah will make room for you. And when you are told: 'Arise!' then arise. Allah will raise those who have believed among you and those who were given knowledge by degrees. And Allah is acquainted with what you do" [58:11].

This verse of the Qur'an holds divine instructions and rules of social conduct directed at avoiding discord, spreading care and friendliness among people, and maximizing the benefit of circles of knowledge when we are in them. These rules address assemblies, social gatherings, groups, and study circles. The first rule commands making space for newcomers when sitting in an assembly, allowing them to sit down, feel welcome and part of the assembly. This brings peace and strengthens ties.

The Messenger of Allah, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam, was so beloved by his Companions (Sahabah) that naturally, they sought to sit as close to him as possible, and if that meant they had to compete for a better place close to him, they did. This verse was, therefore, revealed, to address social manners and etiquette. Qatadah, of the great Successor (Tabi'ee) generation that came after the Companions, said commenting on this verse that "it was revealed concerning assemblies of learning and discussion, for when they saw someone approaching, the Companions used to be reluctant to concede a space for him in their assemblies with Allah's Messenger, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam-and thus Allah's instruction to make space for each other."

Several of the sayings of the Prophet, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam, speak to the merits of making space at assemblies. One of these quoted by Ibn Umar says: "Let no person get up only to have another to sit in his place, but rather make room and enlarge your circle" (Bukhari and Muslim). Another version cited by Ahmad, says: "...but rather make space, and Allah will make space for you."

When room is made for someone, it should be accepted, and the person should sit down next to those who made it, and thank them. The Prophet, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam, said: "When people take their places and sit, and a man invites a [Muslim] brother of his and makes room for him, let the latter take it. It is a generous gesture offered to him, so let him sit there" (Tabari).

Making room for newcomers in a gathering is a rule of refined conduct promoted by the Prophet Muhammad, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam, and is characteristic of Islam. It is a sign of affability and mutual affection of all Muslims. It is both a courtesy and a good deed. When someone arrives late to a learning session, the people already there should make room, so that the latecomer may sit down , listen, and benefit from the discussion, rather than have him or her turn back with the excuse that no place is available or that the place is too tight, thus denying one the opportunity of learning. One hadith states that while Allah's Messenger, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam, was sitting, three people approached. One of them found an opening in the circle and joined it. Another sat behind other people. The third turned back and left. Allah's Messenger said: "Shall I give you an account of these three? The first took refuge with Allah. As for the second, he felt shy and sat behind the people. The third turned away, so Allah turned away from him."

We should not separate people from each other, for Allah's Messenger, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam, said: "It is not lawful for any man to separate two people without their permission" (Abu Dawud and Tirmithi). Such separation may inconvenience them, for they may have special affection toward each other or may have been discussing a private matter. So separating them, by sitting between them, may disturb them.

The Prophet Muhammad, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam, also said: "No one among you should cause a man to stand and then sit in his place" (Bukhari). A person who sits in a place first is more entitled to it. The best practice is for a person joining a group to sit next to the last person in it. Jabir Ibn Samurah said: "When we joined the Prophet, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam, we used to sit where the end was, "meaning at the end of the group in order not to inconvenience anyone and make them get up" (Abu Dawud).

Another important rule of conduct at assemblies is to take the initiative when entering by greeting the people already there. The Prophet, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam, said: "Do not admit a person who does not begin with a greeting" (AbuYa'la).There are many ahadith on the subject of making the salutation of others a common practice. In one of these, the Prophet states: "O People! Spread greetings. Offer food. Keep in touch with your blood relatives. And pray while people are asleep. And you will be admitted into Paradise in peace" (Tirmithi).

When leaving a group, it is proper for a Muslim to commend the people there with salutations of peace, for die Prophet, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam, said: "If one of you joins an assembly, let him greet (the People there). And if he gets up while others are still sitting, let him greet (them). For the former (greeting) is not more of an obligation than the latter" (Ahmed and Abu Dawud).

When Muslims visit one another, they should not stay overly long. Once they have achieved what they came for, they should depart, in order not to inconvenience the host. That is why Allah, subhanahu wa ta'ala, says: "And when you are told, 'Arise,' then arise," which means that when one is asked to get up and leave, one should do so. Abdurrahman ibn Zaid said: "People used to gather at the house of the Prophet, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam, and when they wanted to leave, each desired to be the last to leave him, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam. That made things hard for Allah's Messenger. Therefore, they were ordered to leave."

Advertisement

It is proper for Muslims when sitting with others that they should be both modest and attentive in the way they sit. They should not keep turning their heads in all directions without cause, lest they arouse suspicion and wariness. Nor should they keep clearing their throats for no reason.

If someone sneezes and then praises Allah (saying alhamdulillah), the people around should respond with a prayer for Allah's mercy for him. When yawning, the mouth should be covered and further yawning resisted as much as possible. One should not sit with one's back to other people. Moreover, in a group of three, it is not right for two to talk intimately and privately, leaving the third out.

Finally, let the assembly conclude with the supplication mentioned in a hadith of the Prophet, sallallahu alayhe wa sallam, narrated by Abu Hurairah winch says: "When a person sits in an assembly, having engaged in much idle talk, and then says, before getting up: 'Glory and praise be to you my lord. There is no God other than You. I pray for your pardon and repent to you'-Allah forgives for him what he has done [meaning the idle talk] in that assembly" (Tirmithi).

title: Manners of Greeting with Salam
text:
When to Seek Permission to Enter Someone's House

• If the house is not your house, and you want to enter it, then you must ask permission. • If the house is your house, and no one else is living in it, then you may enter without asking anyone for permission. • Seeking permission to enter someone's house is waived when: 1- it is not possible to give permission; 2- asking permission could result in harm; 3- for the one who has a right and asking for permission will cause his right to be lost. • Praising other people which means speaking highly of someone for some good that he did, or for some good characteristics that he possesses is permissible in Islam.

title: 100 Islamic Manners: Incorporate Sunnah into Daily Life
text:
1. Greeting with Salaam Sunnah: "When you meet one another, greet with a greeting from Allah, blessed and good." [Sunan Abu Dawood, Book 43, Hadith 5178] Quranic Reference: "And when you are greeted with a greeting, greet in return with what is better than it or at least return it equally." [Quran 4:86] 2. Smiling at Others Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Your smile for your brother is a charity." [Sunan At-Tirmidhi, Book 25, Hadith 1956] 3. Being Truthful Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Truthfulness leads to righteousness, and righteousness leads to Paradise." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 73, Hadith 116] Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Leave that which makes you doubt for that which does not make you doubt, for truthfulness is certainty and tranquility, while lying is doubt and confusion." [Sunan At-Tirmidhi, Book 7, Hadith 2518] Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Truthfulness leads to righteousness, and righteousness leads to Paradise. Falsehood leads to wickedness, and wickedness leads to Hell." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 73, Hadith 116] Quranic Reference: "And do not mix the truth with falsehood or conceal the truth while you know [it]." [Quran 2:42] Quranic Reference: "O you who have believed, fear Allah and be with those who are true." [Quran 9:119] 4. Avoiding Gossip Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Do you know what backbiting is?" They said, "Allah and His Messenger know best." He said, "It is to mention about your brother something that he dislikes." [Sahih Muslim, Book 32, Hadith 6265] Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day, let him speak good or remain silent." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 78, Hadith 611] Quranic Reference: "And do not pursue that of which you have no knowledge." [Quran 17:36] Quranic Reference: "And do not spy or backbite each other." [Quran 49:12] 5. Being Humble Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Whoever humbles himself for the sake of Allah, Allah will exalt him." [Sahih Muslim, Book 37, Hadith 6627] Quranic Reference: "And the servants of the Most Merciful are those who walk upon the earth easily, and when the ignorant address them [harshly], they say [words of] peace." [Quran 25:63] 6. Keeping Promises Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "The signs of a hypocrite are three: Whenever he speaks, he tells a lie; whenever he promises, he breaks it; and whenever he is entrusted, he betrays his trust." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 73, Hadith 117] Quranic Reference: "O you who have believed, fulfill [all] contracts." [Quran 5:1] 7. Being Patient Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "No one is given a gift better and more comprehensive than patience." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 56, Hadith 151] Quranic Reference: "O you who have believed, seek help through patience and prayer. Indeed, Allah is with the patient." [Quran 2:153] Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "The believer who associates with people and bears their annoyance with patience will have a greater reward than the believer who does not associate with people and does not put up with their annoyance." [Sunan At-Tirmidhi, Book 48, Hadith 2515] Quranic Reference: "And those who are patient, seeking the countenance of their Lord, and establish prayer and spend from what We have provided for them secretly and publicly and prevent evil with good - those will have the good consequence of [this] home." [Quran 13:22] Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "The prayer of a person in congregation is twenty-seven times superior to that of a person praying alone." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 10, Hadith 509] Quranic Reference: "O you who have believed, seek help through patience and prayer. Indeed, Allah is with the patient." [Quran 2:153] Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "No fatigue, nor disease, nor sorrow, nor sadness, nor hurt, nor distress befalls a Muslim, even if it were the prick he receives from a thorn, but that Allah expiates some of his sins for that." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 70, Hadith 545] Quranic Reference: "And We will surely test you with something of fear and hunger and a loss of wealth and lives and fruits, but give good tidings to the patient." [Quran 2:155] 8. Helping Others Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Whoever relieves a Muslim of a burden from the burdens of this world, Allah will relieve him of a burden from the burdens on the Day of Judgement." [Sahih Muslim, Book 35, Hadith 6518] Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "The one who looks after a widow or a poor person is like a Mujahid (warrior) who fights for Allah's cause." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 70, Hadith 575] Quranic Reference: "So as for the orphan, do not oppress [him]. And as for the petitioner, do not repel [him]." [Quran 93:9-10] Quranic Reference: "And cooperate in righteousness and piety, but do not cooperate in sin and aggression." [Quran 5:2] 9. Being Grateful Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "He who does not thank people, does not thank Allah." [Sunan Abi Dawood, Book 41, Hadith 4811] Quranic Reference: "If you are grateful, I will surely increase you [in favor]." [Quran 14:7] 10. Seeking Knowledge Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Seeking knowledge is obligatory upon every Muslim." [Sunan Ibn Majah, Book 1, Hadith 224] Quranic Reference: "Say, 'Are those who know equal to those who do not know?' Only they will remember [who are] people of understanding." [Quran 39:9] 11. Being Just Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Indeed, those who are just will be in the presence of Allah upon pulpits of light." [Sahih Muslim, Book 33, Hadith 6511] Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Give the worker his wages before his sweat dries." [Sunan Ibn Majah, Book 16, Hadith 2443] Quranic Reference: "O you who have believed, fulfill [all] contracts." [Quran 5:1] Quranic Reference: "Indeed, Allah commands you to render trusts to whom they are due and when you judge between people to judge with justice." [Quran 4:58] 12. Showing Mercy Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "He who does not show mercy to people, Allah will not show mercy to him." [Sahih Muslim, Book 30, Hadith 5736] Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "The merciful are shown mercy by The Merciful. Be merciful on the earth, and you will be shown mercy from above." [Sunan At-Tirmidhi, Book 27, Hadith 1924] Quranic Reference: "So by mercy from Allah, [O Muhammad], you were lenient with them." [Quran 3:159] 13. Being Charitable Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "The believer's shade on the Day of Resurrection will be his charity." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 24, Hadith 441] Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Protect yourselves from Hell-fire even by giving a piece of date as charity." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 24, Hadith 498] Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "The upper hand is better than the lower hand (i.e., he who gives in charity is better than him who takes it)." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 24, Hadith 508] Quranic Reference: "But whoever volunteers excess, it is better for him." [Quran 2:184] Quranic Reference: "And establish prayer and give zakah and bow with those who bow [in worship and obedience]." [Quran 2:43] Quranic Reference: "The example of those who spend their wealth in the way of Allah is like a seed [of grain] that sprouts seven ears; in every ear is a hundred grains." [Quran 2:261] 14. Lowering the Gaze Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Do not follow a glance with another glance." [Sunan Abi Dawood, Book 33, Hadith 2144] Quranic Reference: "Tell the believing men to reduce [some] of their vision and guard their private parts." [Quran 24:30] 15. Speaking Kindly Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Speak a good word or remain silent." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 78, Hadith 611] Quranic Reference: "And speak to people good [words]." [Quran 2:83] 16. Maintaining Cleanliness Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Cleanliness is half of faith." [Sahih Muslim, Book 2, Hadith 432] Quranic Reference: "Indeed, Allah loves those who are constantly repentant and loves those who purify themselves." [Quran 2:222] 17. Praying Regularly Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Between a man and disbelief and paganism is the abandonment of Salat (prayer)." [Sahih Muslim, Book 1, Hadith 146] Quranic Reference: "Indeed, prayer has been decreed upon the believers a decree of specified times." [Quran 4:103] 18. Giving the Right Amount in Trade Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Give the worker his wages before his sweat dries." [Sunan Ibn Majah, Book 16, Hadith 2443] Quranic Reference: "And give full measure when you measure, and weigh with an even balance. That is the best [way] and best in result." [Quran 17:35] 19. Avoiding Riba (Interest) Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "May Allah curse the one who accepts usury, the one who pays it, the one who records it, and the two witnesses to it." [Sunan Abi Dawood, Book 23, Hadith 3333] Quranic Reference: "Allah has permitted trade and has forbidden interest." [Quran 2:275] Quranic Reference: "Those who consume interest cannot stand [on the Day of Resurrection] except as one stands who is being beaten by Satan into insanity." [Quran 2:275] 20. Showing Kindness to Parents Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Paradise lies at the feet of your mother." [Sunan An-Nasa'i, Book 25, Hadith 3104] Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "A man asked the Prophet (pbuh), 'Who is most deserving of my good companionship?' He said, 'Your mother.' The man asked, 'Then who?' He said, 'Your mother.' The man asked again, 'Then who?' He said, 'Your mother.' The man asked once more, 'Then who?' He said, 'Then your father.'" [Sahih Muslim, Book 32, Hadith 6181] Quranic Reference: "And We have enjoined upon man [care] for his parents." [Quran 31:14] Quranic Reference: "And your Lord has decreed that you not worship except Him, and to parents, good treatment." [Quran 17:23] 21. Avoiding Envy Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Beware of envy, for it consumes good deeds just as fire consumes wood." [Sunan Abi Dawood, Book 41, Hadith 4903] Quranic Reference: "And from the evil of an envier when he envies." [Quran 113:5] 23. Avoiding Anger Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "The strong man is not the one who can overpower others. Rather, the strong man is the one who controls himself when he gets angry." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 73, Hadith 135] Quranic Reference: "And those who restrain anger and who pardon the people." [Quran 3:134] 24. Forgiving Others Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Be merciful to others and you will receive mercy. Forgive others and Allah will forgive you." [Musnad Ahmad, Hadith 7001] Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Whoever suffers an injury and forgives (the person responsible), Allah will raise his status to a higher degree and remove one of his sins." [Sunan Ibn Majah, Book 13, Hadith 3964] Quranic Reference: "And let them pardon and overlook. Would you not like that Allah should forgive you?" [Quran 24:22] 25. Being Generous Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "The generous man is close to Allah, close to Paradise, close to the people, and far from the Hellfire." [Sunan At-Tirmidhi, Book 36, Hadith 1961] Quranic Reference: "Indeed, Allah commands you to render trusts to whom they are due." [Quran 4:58] 26. Showing Good Manners Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "The most beloved of you to me are those who have the best manners." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 73, Hadith 56] Quranic Reference: "And lower your wing to those who follow you of the believers." [Quran 26:215] 27. Avoiding Extravagance Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Eat, drink, give charity, and wear nice clothes, as long as it does not involve extravagance or arrogance." [Sunan Ibn Majah, Book 29, Hadith 3605] Quranic Reference: "Indeed, the wasteful are brothers of the devils." [Quran 17:27] 28. Maintaining Trusts Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "When a man tells something and goes away, it is a trust." [Sunan Abi Dawood, Book 41, Hadith 4868] Quranic Reference: "Indeed, Allah commands you to render trusts to whom they are due." [Quran 4:58] 29. Being Kind to Orphans Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "The one who cares for an orphan and myself will be together in Paradise like this," and he held his two fingers together. [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 78, Hadith 6005] Quranic Reference: "So as for the orphan, do not oppress [him]." [Quran 93:9] 30. Being Content Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Riches do not mean having a great amount of property, but riches is self-contentment." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 76, Hadith 453] Quranic Reference: "But perhaps you hate a thing and it is good for you." [Quran 2:216] 31. Taking Care of the Environment Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "If a Muslim plants a tree or sows seeds, and then a bird, or a person, or an animal eats from it, it is regarded as a charitable gift (Sadaqah) for him." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 42, Hadith 2320] Quranic Reference: "It is He who has made you successors upon the earth." [Quran 35:39] 32. Avoiding Backbiting Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Do you know what backbiting is?" They said, "Allah and His Messenger know best." He said, "It is to mention about your brother something that he dislikes." [Sahih Muslim, Book 32, Hadith 6265] Quranic Reference: "And do not spy or backbite each other." [Quran 49:12] 33. Honoring Guests Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day should be hospitable to his guest." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 78, Hadith 47] Quranic Reference: "And they give food in spite of love for it to the needy, the orphan, and the captive." [Quran 76:8] 34. Being Moderate in Worship Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "This religion is easy. None overburdens himself in his religion but that it overcomes him." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 2, Hadith 38] Quranic Reference: "Allah intends for you ease and does not intend for you hardship." [Quran 2:185] 35. Reconciliation Between People Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "He who makes peace between the people by inventing good information or saying good things is not a liar." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 49, Hadith 857] Quranic Reference: "And if two factions among the believers should fight, then make settlement between the two." [Quran 49:9] 36. Respecting the Elderly Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "He is not one of us who does not show mercy to our young and respect to our elders." [Sunan At-Tirmidhi, Book 46, Hadith 1919] Quranic Reference: None specific, but respecting elders is a general Islamic principle. 37. Avoiding Suspicion Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Beware of suspicion, for suspicion is the worst of false tales." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 78, Hadith 134] Quranic Reference: "O you who have believed, avoid much [negative] assumption. Indeed, some assumption is sin." [Quran 49:12] 38. Performing the Five Daily Prayers Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Between a man and disbelief and paganism is the abandonment of Salat (prayer)." [Sahih Muslim, Book 1, Hadith 146] Quranic Reference: "Indeed, prayer has been decreed upon the believers a decree of specified times." [Quran 4:103] 39. Fasting in Ramadan Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Whoever fasts during Ramadan out of sincere faith and hoping to attain Allah's rewards, then all his past sins will be forgiven." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 2, Hadith 37] Quranic Reference: "O you who have believed, decreed upon you is fasting as it was decreed upon those before you that you may become righteous." [Quran 2:183] 40. Performing Hajj (Pilgrimage) Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Whoever performs Hajj to this House (Ka'bah) and does not commit any obscenity or wrongdoing, he will come out as the day he was born - pure and free from sins." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 25, Hadith 1521] Quranic Reference: "And Hajj to the House (Ka'bah) is a duty that mankind owes to Allah, those who can afford the expenses." [Quran 3:97] 41. Observing the Rights of Neighbors Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Jibril (Gabriel) kept advising me about treating the neighbors kindly and politely so much so that I thought he would order me to make them my heirs." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 78, Hadith 43] Quranic Reference: "Worship Allah and associate nothing with Him, and to parents do good, and to relatives, orphans, the needy, the near neighbor, the neighbor farther away." [Quran 4:36] 42. Avoiding Arrogance Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "Whoever has an atom's weight of pride in his heart will not enter Paradise." [Sahih Muslim, Book 1, Hadith 164] Quranic Reference: "Indeed, Allah does not like everyone self-deluded and boastful." [Quran 4:36] 43. Being Honest in Trade Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "The honest and trustworthy merchant will be with the Prophets, the truthful, and the martyrs." [Sunan At-Tirmidhi, Book 12, Hadith 1209] Quranic Reference: "And give full measure when you measure, and weigh with an even balance." [Quran 17:35] 44. Being Punctual Sunnah: The Prophet (pbuh) said, "The best of you are those who are best in fulfilling (rights)." [Sahih al-Bukhari, Book 73, Hadith 110] Quranic Reference: "Indeed, prayer has been decreed upon the believers a decree of specified times." [Quran 4:103] 45. title: Islamic Social Etiquette
text:
Umm Saad highlights the noble mannerism and grace portrayed by Allah’s Messenger (sa) in times when ignorance and indecency was rife.

Allah (swt) states in the holy Quran: “Indeed, in the Messenger of Allah (swt) Muhammad (sa) you have a good example to follow, if you hope for (the meeting with) Allah (swt) and the Last Day, and remember Allah (swt) much.” (Al-Ahzab 33:21)

Therefore, the Prophet (sa) is the best role model for every Muslim that has provided numerous examples in every aspect of human behaviour. The following pearls from his social etiquettes are enlightening.

Spreading the greeting of Salam

The Messenger of Allah (sa) commanded us to do seven things: to visit the sick, to attend funerals, to bless a Muslim, when he sneezes, to support the weak, to help the one, who is oppressed, to spread Salam (peace), and to help people fulfil their oaths. (Bukhari, Muslim)

He also said: “By the One, in whose hand is my soul, you will not enter Paradise, until you believe, and you will not believe, until you love one another. Shall I not tell you of something that if you do, you will love one another? Spread Salam amongst yourselves.” (Muslim)

Unfortunately, today in Islamic societies this greeting has been replaced by foreign ones, especially among new generations, who are either ashamed or consider it old-fashioned to use the Islamic greeting. Obviously, they are unaware that a simple ‘Assalam Alaikum Wa Rahmatullahi Wa Barakatahu’ can earn them thirty rewards from Allah (swt)!

Not entering anyone’s house without his permission

Allah (swt) commands: “O you who believe! Enter not houses other than your own, until you have asked permission and saluted those in them: that is best for you, in order that you may take heed.” (An-Nur 24:27)

Islam urges Muslims to do the following, when visiting others: “Whenever the Prophet (sa) came to a door seeking permission to enter, he did not stand facing it. He would stand to the right or to the left, and if he was given permission, he would enter; otherwise, he would leave.” (Bukhari)

Impatiently ringing the doorbell, yelling out the in mates name, and grumbling, when the person we had intended to visit is unavailable, are signs of impoliteness and impertinence. They have no room in a Muslim’s life.

Sitting wherever one finds room in a gathering

In a gathering, a Muslim should sit wherever he finds space. He is neither to push through the people in order to sit at the head of the gathering, nor make another give up his space for him. The Prophet (sa) taught his companions to adopt these etiquettes, when joining a gathering.

Jabir Ibn Samurah (rta) said: “When we came to the Prophet (sa), we would sit, wherever we found room.” (Abu Dawood and Tirmidhi)

The Messenger of Allah (sa) said: “None of you should make another get up, then sit in his place. All of you should move up and make space (for the latecomer).” (Bukhari, Muslim)

The basic instruction is to accommodate and show courtesy. Nowadays, it is common not to leave any space available, because of improper seating arrangements, and the latecomer is usually forced to stand. Similarly, some make grand arrivals without realizing the disturbance they cause to an ongoing gathering or speech.

Avoiding yawning in a gathering

The Prophet (sa) advised Muslims: “If any of you wants to yawn, then let him suppress it as much as possible.” (Bukhari, Muslim)

If the urge to yawn cannot be resisted, then a Muslim should cover his mouth with his hand. The Prophet (sa) commanded: “If any of you yawns, let him cover his mouth with his hand, so that the Shaytan does not enter.” (Muslim)

Yawning is not only rude but a sign of boredom that may hurt the feelings of others. Even the very sophisticated manage to shock you, when they open their mouths as wide as a hippopotamus in the middle of a conversation.

Following the Islamic etiquette, when sneezing

Islam also teaches a Muslim, what he should say, when he sneezes, and what he should say, when he hears another sneeze.

Abu Hurairah (rta) said: “The Prophet (sa) said: ‘Allah (swt) likes the act of sneezing and dislikes the act of yawning. When any one of you sneezes and says ‘Alhamdulillah’, then he has the right to hear every Muslim say – ‘Yarhamuk Allah’. But yawning is from Shaytan, so if anyone of you feels the urge to yawn, he should resist it as much as he can, for when any of you yawns, the Shaytan laughs at him.’” (Bukhari)

Not looking into other people’s houses

A true Muslim does not spy on his host or pry into that, which does not concern him. The Prophet (sa) warned those, who let their gaze wander in gatherings in an attempt to see things that are none of their business.

The Prophet (sa) said: “Whoever looks into someone’s house without his permission, then it is permissible for the people of the house to take his eyes out.” (Muslim)

Not finding fault with others

The Prophet (sa) issued a stern warning against the danger of slandering other people’s honour and exposing their faults.

The Prophet (sa) said: “Do not hurt the feelings of the servants of Allah (swt), do not embarrass them, do not seek to expose their faults; whoever seeks to expose the faults of his Muslim brother, Allah (swt) will seek to expose his faults and expose him, even if he hides in the innermost part of his home.” (Ahmad)

Apart from the above, there are numerous other social etiquettes that will be discussed in future issues, Insha’Allah.

title: The Islamic Greeting and it’s Etiquette
text:
Bismillahir ar-Rahmanir ar-Rahim

Islam has professed the use of the Islamic greeting when encountering another Muslim or leaving the company of another Muslim because it unifies the hearts and strengthens bonds between Muslims.

Muslim reported that the Prophet (Salallahu Alayhi Wasallam) said, “I swear by the one whose hand my soul is in that you will not enter paradise until you believe. And you won’t be believed until you love one another. May I tell you something, that if you practice it you will love another, spread the (salam) Islamic greeting among you.” This makes it clear to us, that spreading salam among Muslims is the first step towards paradise. This is because spreading salam leads to increasing the love between our hearts. And the increase of love between our hearts will increase the Iman, (faith).

An authentic hadith reported by Tirmidhi and Ibn Majah that the Prophet (Salallahu Alayhi Wasallam) said: “Oh you people, spread salam among you, serve the food, behave kindly with your blood relations, and offer prayer at night when others are asleep, and you will enter paradise safely.” And Imams Bukhari and Muslim reported that a man asked the prophet (Salallahu Alayhi Wasallam) “what in Islam is the best?” He (Salallahu Alayhi Wasallam) answered, “To feed people and to say salam to everyone whether you know them or not.”

What is the history of the Islamic greeting, when did it start, and who was the one who chose it?

Bukhari and Muslim reported that the Prophet (Salallahu Alayhi Wasallam) said, “When Allah created Adam he told him to go and say Assalamu Alikum to a group of Angels and listen to their reply. It is your greeting and the greeting of your descendants. Adam went and said: Assalamu Alikum they said Assalamu Alikum Wa Rahmatulah.”

The complete form for the Islamic greeting is Assalamu Alilkum Wa Rahmatulah Wa Barakatuh meaning peace, mercy, and blessings be upon from Allah (Subhanhu Wa Ta’ala). This is because Abu-Dawood and Tirmidhi reported in a good hadith that a man came to the Prophet (Salallahu Alayhi Wasallam) and said, “Assalamu Alikum.” The prophet responded and the man sat down. The Prophet said, “Ten rewards.” Another man came and said, “Assalamu Alikum Wa Rahmatullh.” The prophet responded and the man sat down. The prophet said, “twenty rewards.”

Then another man came and said: Assalamu Alakum Wa Rahmatulah Wa Barakatuh. The prophet responded and the man sat down. The prophet said, “thirty rewards.”

The Scholars have agreed that starting with salam is highly recommended. And responding is obligatory because Allah (Subhanhu Wa Ta’ala) said in surat An-Nisaa, (verse 86), what can be translated as, “When a courteous greeting is offered to you, meet it with a greeting still more courteous, or at least of equal courtesy.”

It is enough for one to say the Islamic greeting to a group and it is enough for one of the group to return it. This is the meaning of the two ahadith that were reported by Abu Dawood and Malik.

From the Etiquette of Salam:

The one who comes greets the Muslims that are present.

The one who is riding greets the one who is walking.

The one who is walking greets the one who is sitting.

The smaller group greets the bigger group.

The young greet the elder.

Imams Bukhari and Muslim reported that the Prophet (Salallahu Alayhi Wasallam) said, “A rider should greet a pedestrian, a pedestrian should greet one who is sitting, and a small party should greet a large party, a younger should greet an elder one.”

Salams are recommended when leaving as well as when you meet. Abu-Dawoud, and Tirmidhi reported in a good hadith that the Prophet (Salallahu Alayhi Wasallam) said, “When one of you joins a gathering he should greet those present; and when he leave them he should greet them because the first salutation is not better than the last one.”





What does Islam say about saying salams to the People of the Book?

The majority of scholars reported that starting with Assalamu Alikum is not permitted. They refer to the hadith of the prophet that was reported by Imam Muslim in which the Prophet (Salallahu Alayhi Wasallam) said, “Don’t start with the (salam) Islamic greeting when encountering Jews or Christians.”

Some scholars see no problem in starting with the Islamic greeting. Some of the Shafies agree with this. This is the opinion of Ibn-Abbas one of the companions of the prophet. He said that this hadith was special for the Jewish of Quraizah, not for all of the people of the book.

What if the people of the book start with the salams with the Muslims. Some of the scholars, like Ahnaf say that it is allowed to returnsalam and others say it’s obligatory.

Ibn Abbass said, “Whoever says Assalamu Alakum to you, you have to return his greeting even if he was a Majos (fire-worshipper). He was referring to a verse from surat An-Nisaa (verse 86), what can be translated as, “When a courteous greeting is offered to you, meet it with a greeting still more courteous, or at least of equal courtesy.”

The scholar had agreed upon starting the greeting with the non-Muslims is allowed with any word but Assalamu Alikum, like good morning, how are you?

When meeting another Muslim shaking hands is highly recommended, along with a great smile, because it increases the love and respect among Muslims.

It was reported by Imam Bukhari that Qatadah asked Anass (RadiAllahu Anhu) if shaking hands was practiced by the companion at the time of the Prophet (Salallahu Alayhi Wasallam). He said, “Yes.”

Shaking hands with another Muslim will result in forgiveness from Allah (Subhanhu Wa Ta’ala). Abu Dawood and Tirmidhi reported that the Prophet (Salallahu Alayhi Wasallam) said, “If Muslims meet and shake hands with each other, they will be forgiven before they leave.”

Tirmidhi reported a good hadith that a man said: “O messenger of Allah if one of us meets his brother or friend, should he bend down to him? The Prophet said, “ No.” He asked should he hug him and kiss him? The Prophet answered, “No.” He asked should he take his hand and shake it. The Prophet answered, “Yes.”

Tirmidhi reported that Anass (RadiAllahu Anhu) said, “When the prophet use to meet a man, he shook hands with him and the prophet (Salallahu Alayhi Wasallam) would not pull away his hand until the man would pull his hand away first.”

title: Arabic Greetings And farewells: Beginner’s Guide
text:
Wherever you go in the world, you’ll hear Arabic being spoken. It’s a fascinating language and many people are deciding to take it up. Today, it’s considered one of the fastest-growing languages in the world. 25 countries in the world also have Arabic as an official or spoken language, so it can be useful for work, travel, and social opportunities too.

Whatever your reasons for learning, learning some basic Arabic greetings and farewells is a good way to begin. Keep reading to learn more or take your first Arabic lessons online.

How do you say ‘hello’ in Arabic?

In Arabic, ‘hello’ can be expressed as ‘As-salamu alaikum’ (السلام عليكم), meaning ‘peace be upon you’, or ‘Marhaba’ (مرحبا). These greetings are commonly used across Arabic-speaking regions, conveying warmth and respect.

Understanding Arabic greetings and their cultural significance

If you need to know how to say hello in Arabic, the first distinction you need to make is between religious and non-religious greetings.

Not all Arabic speakers are Muslims, however, the most common way to say hello in Arabic is the Islamic greeting “As-salamu alaikum”, which means “Peace be upon you”. The non-religious way to greet someone in Arabic would be to say “ahlan”. Both of these Arabic greetings have set responses:

Greeting Response Hello (religious) As-salamu alaikum السلام عليكم Wa-alaikum as-salam وعليكم السلام Hello (non-religious) Ahlan أهلاً Ahlan beek أهلاً بيك

Greetings in Arabic change depending on the time of day. Saying “good morning” in Arabic is “sabah al kheir” and “kheir” means “goodness”. The literal translation is “morning of goodness” and the response to this would be to change “goodness” to an equally positive word, such as “flowers” or “light”.

Greeting Response Good morning Sabah al-kheir صباح الخير Morning of light Sabah al-noor صباح النور Good evening Masaa al-kheir مساء الخير Evening of flowers Masaa al-ward مساء الورد

As with English, the equivalent of “good night” is not often used as a greeting but rather when saying goodbye.

Formal greetings and responses in Arabic

There are both religious and non-religious ways to greet and respond to others in Arabic. Saying hello is often followed by the question “how are you?” There are several ways to say this depending on who you are speaking to.

Greeting Response How are you? Kaefa haaluk? كيف حالك Good thanks (religious) Bekheir alhamdulilah بخير الحمدلله Good thanks (non-religious) Bekheir shukran بخير شكراً And you? Wa ant? (m) Wa anti? (f) وأنت؟

Informal greetings and responses in Arabic

There is an exhaustive list because each dialect of Arabic has a different way of saying this but here are some examples:

Greeting Response Levantine Arabic How’s it going? Keefak? كيفك؟ I’m fine Mneeh (m) Mneeha (f) منيح Egyptian Arabic Akhbarik eeh? أخبارك إيه؟ Kwayis (m) Kwayisa (f) كويس

Arabic basic phrases

Beyond the first encounter, you will definitely want to learn more ways of interacting with your Arabic speaking counterparts. You’ll need to be polite, saying thanks and even apologizing at times. Later, you’ll also need to be able to ask some basic questions in Arabic. So let’s dig in.

Saying thanks and responding

Phrase Response Thank you Shukran شكراً You’re welcome Afwan عفواً Thank you very much Shukran jazeelan شكراً جزيلاً May god reward you (religious) Jazakallah kheir جزاك الله خير And you Wa iyak kheir وإياك خير

With family and friends, it is common to say “min eyooni” instead of “afwan”. It literally means “from my eyes”.

Apologizing in Arabic

These Arabic words and phrases for apologies increase in intensity. You may use the first when trying to get past someone in the street or if you didn’t hear what someone said. However, the latter two are for apologizing for something you did wrong. “Samahni” in particular is quite formal, and used if you have really offended someone.

Phrase Response Excuse me / pardon me Afwan / lo samaht عفواً / لو سمحت Forgiveness Al-afuw العفو Sorry Asif أسف No worries Hasal kheir حصل خير Forgive me Samahni سامحني

Basic questions

Now that you’ve mastered a few first words, you’re going to be eager to dive deeper. Here are some basic questions to get to know someone better, and a couple that might make your life easier when traveling in an Arabic-speaking country.

Phrase Response What’s your name? Ma huwa ismuk? Shu ismuk? (informal) ما هو اسمك؟ شو اسمك؟ My name is… Ismee… [name] Ana…[name] إسمي… أنا … Where are you from? Min aina ant? Inta min ween? (informal) من أين أنت؟ إنت من وين؟ I am from… Ana min… أنا من… Do you speak another language? Hel tatakalum lugha ukhra? هل تتكلم لغة أخرى؟ Yes, I speak… No, sorry. Na’am, itakalam… La, asif. نعم، أتكلم… لا، أسف. Pardon me, where is the restroom? Lo samaht, ain al hamam? لو سمحت، أين الحمام؟ There Hunak هناك How much is this? Bikam hatha? بكم هذا؟ `

Arabic farewells

There is also a religious and non-religious way of saying goodbye in Arabic. It is worth mentioning that ”ila al liqaa” is not often used since it is very formal. It literally means “until we meet again” and is really only heard on news programs or in Modern Standard Arabic cartoons.

Unlike saying hello, responses to saying goodbye are often the same as the greeting and can be used interchangeably.

Greeting and response Bye (religious) Fi aman illa Allah ma’ik في أمان الله الله معك Bye (non-religious) Ma’assalama Illa al-liqaa مع السلامة إلا اللقاء Goodnight Tisbah ‘ala kheir تصبح على خير

Etiquette in Arabic countries

Arabic is a language that places a lot of importance on etiquette and politeness. In Arab culture, between friends and family, this is less important than with strangers and superiors, but even then there are still certain rules.

This is not always reflected in language and there are a number of common gestures. For example, it’s common to stand up when someone enters the room, or wait until the host is sitting at the table and invites everyone to start eating.

Referring to elders in Arabic is important. Usually, first names are not used unless you are told to or you are a similar age and familiar with someone. Formally, you can refer to someone as “Parent of” their eldest child, and informally you can call them aunt or uncle.

To an elder or a stranger you might use the formal pronoun “hadartik”. For example, “meen hadartik” is a polite way of asking “who are you?” This is particularly common to use while speaking on the phone to ask who is calling.

Phrase Please Min fadlek / lo samaht من فضلك / لو سمحت Welcome Ahlan wa sahlan أهلاً وسهلاً Please come in / please help yourself Tfadel (m) Tfadelee (f) تفضل تفضلي Mother of… / Father of… Umm… (f) / Abo…(m) أم… / أبو… Auntie / uncle Khala (f), Amo (m) خالة / عام Formal pronoun Hadartik حضرتك

The first step on the path to learning Arabic

So there you have it, some basic Arabic greetings and simple phrases so you can hold a polite conversation. These are the essential ingredients you’ll need to start speaking and interacting with real Arabic-speaking people. They will open the door to new knowledge, a fascinating culture and untold opportunities in the future.

If you are interested in learning more about Arab culture and language with the help of a teacher, take your first online Arabic class on Preply.

title: The Meaning and Etiquette of Muslim Greetings
text:
The Beauty of Muslim Greetings: A Gateway to Connection and Blessings

The Muslim greeting, “As-salamu alaykum” (peace be upon you), is far more than a simple exchange of words. It is a profound act of worship, a reminder of faith, and a means of strengthening bonds among Muslims. Rooted in the teachings of the Quran and Sunnah, this beautiful greeting carries deep spiritual significance and conveys the core values of Islam: peace, kindness, and mutual respect.

In this article, we’ll explore the meaning and etiquette of the Muslim greeting, its rewards, and how it serves as a cornerstone of building harmonious relationships in the Muslim community.

What Does “As-Salamu Alaykum” Mean?

The Arabic phrase “As-salamu alaykum” translates to “Peace be upon you.” This greeting embodies a wish for peace, security, and blessings from Allah for the person being addressed. It’s a way of expressing good intentions and fostering unity among Muslims.

The complete version of the greeting is:

“As-salamu alaykum wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuh”

(Peace be upon you, and the mercy of Allah, and His blessings)

This extended version adds an even greater sense of goodwill and invokes Allah’s mercy and blessings for the recipient.

Why Is the Muslim Greeting Important?

1. A Sunnah of the Prophet (peace be upon him)

The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) placed great emphasis on the practice of exchanging greetings. He said:

“You will not enter Paradise until you believe, and you will not believe until you love one another. Shall I tell you something that will increase love among you? Spread Salam among yourselves.”

(Sahih Muslim)

This hadith highlights the greeting as a means to strengthen bonds of brotherhood and sisterhood, fostering a sense of community and mutual love.

2. A Source of Reward

Greeting others with Salam is not just polite—it’s rewarded by Allah. The Prophet (peace be upon him) said:

“The one who is first to greet with Salam is free from pride.”

(Abu Dawood)

Moreover, responding to Salam is obligatory, making it an interactive act of worship.

The Etiquette of Greeting in Islam

1. Initiating the Greeting

Muslims are encouraged to initiate the greeting whenever they meet others, whether family, friends, or strangers. The Prophet (peace be upon him) taught:

“The one riding should greet the one walking, the one walking should greet the one sitting, and a smaller group should greet a larger group.”

(Sahih al-Bukhari)

2. Responding to Salam

When greeted, it is obligatory to respond with an equal or better greeting, as Allah commands in the Quran:

“And when you are greeted with a greeting, greet in return with one better than it or at least return it.”

(Surah An-Nisa, 4:86)

For example, if someone says “As-salamu alaykum,” a better response would be “Wa alaykum as-salam wa rahmatullahi wa barakatuh.”

3. Greeting Non-Muslims

Muslims are encouraged to extend kindness and good will to all people. When greeting non-Muslims, it is permissible to use phrases such as “Good morning” or “Hello” while maintaining respect and courtesy.

The Power of Greeting: Building Community and Spreading Peace

The greeting of Salam serves as a daily reminder of Islam’s core values—peace, love, and unity. Here’s how it contributes to building a stronger Muslim community:

Fostering Unity:

Greeting others with Salam creates a sense of belonging and reduces barriers between individuals. Promoting Peace:

The wish for peace embedded in the greeting reminds Muslims to embody peace in their actions and words. Strengthening Bonds:

Regularly exchanging Salam strengthens relationships, whether among family members, friends, or fellow community members.

How to Teach and Spread the Practice of Salam

If you want to make Salam a consistent part of your life or teach it to others, consider the following:

Lead by Example: Make it a habit to greet others with Salam, whether at home, in the mosque, or in public.

Make it a habit to greet others with Salam, whether at home, in the mosque, or in public. Teach Your Children: Encourage young Muslims to practice Salam from an early age, explaining its spiritual and social importance.

To deepen your understanding of Islamic etiquette and other teachings, consider joining our Islamic Courses at Iqra Network. With a wide range of courses, you can learn the beauty of Islamic manners and how they enrich daily life.

Conclusion: A Simple Yet Profound Act

The Muslim greeting of Salam is a powerful expression of faith and goodwill. It embodies the essence of Islam by promoting peace, unity, and love among believers. As we practice this beautiful Sunnah, let’s remember the rewards it brings and the relationships it strengthens.

title: SAHIH MUSLIM, Book 26 : The Book of Salutions and Greetings (KITAB AS-SALAM)
text:
KITAB AS-SALAM

(THE BOOK ON SALUTIONS AND GREETINGS)

INTRODUCTION

Just as the face is the index to the mind, in the same way the words of greetings which are exchanged amongst people indicate the spiritual role of a society. The gestures, and the expressions of salutations are, therefore, the indicators of the ideals for which a particular society stands. The common practice with the pre-Islamic Arabs and thi modern West is to greet one another with Good Morning and Good Evening accompanied by a gesture of the hand or the nodding of head. These words have no spiritual and moral significance, but just a wish that one should find one's mornings and evenings happy. The words of greeting which Islam has exhorted its followers to use at the time of meeting are as-Salam-u-'Alaikum which have a deep spiritual and moral significance behind them Since the predominant feature of Islamic faith and practice is peace within and peace without, it has, therefore, been made a watchword which should be repeated on every occasion when two Muslims meet so that the utmost importance of peace should be constantly inculcated in the mind of every Muslim, and he should have full consciousness of the great reality that he lives in this world as a messenger of peace for mankind. peace amongst individuals and nations.-The second important feature of words of greeting in Islam is that they convey the message of peace not only to the person who is greeted but to the whole of the Muslim society as it is the plural pronoun that is used for the blessing of peace. (The pronoun 'Alaikum has a evry wide range and all the Muslims come within its orbit.) The two words as-Salam-u-'Alaikum may be called the irreducible minimum which are essential for greeting one another. The Muslims have been commanded to add to this expression some other words with a view to excelling one another in showering blessing upon the Muslims. The words as-Salam-u-'Alaikum are generally suffixed with these words Rahmat Allah wa Barakaatuh (mercy of Allah and His bleasings). These three words: "peace... ,mercy" and "blessings of Allah" in fact form the sum and substance of Islam and the Muslims are asked to shower upon one another these benedictions. so that they may be able to live in this world and the Hereafter in perfect peace and tranquillity and blessings and mercy of Allah around him. According to Imam Nawawi, greeting with the words of as-Salam-u-'Alaikum is a Sunnah, and responding to it is Wajib (obligatory), but this essentiality is of the nature of Kifaya, meaning thereby that if a few persons out of the whole assembly or group respond to the greeting it will absolve all of the responsibility of response but if no response comes forth from any quarter all are held responsible for it.

Abu Huraira reported Allah's Messenger (may peace be upon him) as saying: The rider should first greet the pedestrian, and the pedestrian the one who is seated and a small group should greet a larger group (with as-Salam-u-'Alaikum).

Abu Talha reported: While We were sitting in front of the houses and talking amongst ourselves, Allah's Messenger (may peace be upon him) happened to come there. He stood by us and said: What about you apd your meetings on the paths? Avoid these meetings on the paths. We said: We were sitting here without (any intention of doing harm to the passers-by) ; we are sitting to discuss matters and to hold conversation amongst ourselves. Thereupon he said: If there is no help (for you but to sit on these paths), then give the paths their rights and these are lowering of the gaze, exchanging of greetings and good conversation.

Abu Sa'id Khudri reported Allah's Apostle (may peace be upon him) as saying : Avoid sitting on the paths. They (the Companions) said: Allah's Messenger, we cannot help but holding our meetings (in these paths) and discuss matters (there). Thereupon Allah's Messenger (may peace be upon him) said: If you insist on holding meetings, then give the path its due right. They said: What are its due rights ? Upon this he said: Lowering the gaze, refraining from doing harm, exchanging of greetings. commanding of good and forbidding from evil.

This hadith has been narrated on the authority of Zaid b. Aslam with the same chain of transmitters.

Abu Huraira reported Allah's Messenger (may peace be upon him) as saying: Five are the rights of a Muslim over his brother: responding to salutation, saying Yarhamuk Allah when anybody sneezes and says al-Hamdulillah, visiting the sick. following the bier.' Abd al-Razzaq said that this hadith has been transmitted as mursal hadith from Zuhri and he then substantiated it on the authority of Ibn Musayyib.

Abu Huraira reported Allah's Messenger (may peace be upon him) as saying: Six are the rights of a Muslim over another Muslim. It was said to him: Allah's Messenger, what are these? Thereupon he said: When you meet him, offer him greetings;when he invites you to a feast accept it. when he seeks your council give him, and when he sneezes and says: "All praise is due to Allah," you say Yarhamuk Allah (may Allah show mercy to you); and when he fails ill visit him; and when he dies follow his bier.

Anas b. Malik reported Allah's Messenger (may peace be upon him) as saying: When the People of the Book offer you salutations, you should say: The same to you.
